text: we're sitting in the living room of the
seed house which is the student
experiment and ecological design our
main goals are to spread ecological
living practices you know our first and
primary goal is outreach if the actions
of this house and with us and we see
that as a failure and our second goal
which is just as important is to reduce
our ecological footprint right here on
site to know our impact on the world and
to make sure it's a positive one we
moved into the house in actually
September of 2007 and the mood was
exciting and uncertain you know we had
been working on this idea for two years
doing a lot of work to try and get it up
off the ground and secure funding and
then we stepped into our house we
dropped our bags and we sat down and we
had a meeting and I was like okay what
now I think seed house is a great
example of you know students trying to
walk the talk you know I mean you get
people engaging in classrooms learning
about things but the opportunity to
actually live in a house where you get
to sort of realize that vision and
practice it's not superficially that
different from a normal house which is
one thing we try to go for you know we
don't want to scare a lot of people away
by being too ridiculously green so one
of our missions is to try and do
sustainability that the average
homeowner could emulate we do we do a
low-flow faucet to reduce our energy use
here we've got a vermicompost thing bin
we use these worms to compost our food
waste and when you use worms it doesn't
smell so you can keep it indoors all
throughout the winter so the worms will
eat up the food waste that we put in and
they'll poop it out and some really nice
rich soil
this bucket you put under the tub faucet
when you're running the water waiting
for it to get odd because even though
it'd be great if we all took really
really short cold showers all the time
it's really hard when the weather is so
cold we have another bucket under the
sink there's a pipe that's been
unscrewed so that the water from the
sink you just go straight to the bucket
and both of these things the water
coming from here is obviously a little
bit dirtier because it's got toothpaste
in it and so been whatever else people
are using at the sink but what we do
then is we put it in the toilet tank and
once you flush this will empty out and
you can just pour your water back in but
we actually don't even flush that often
because we had some policies how into
flush yellow let it Mellow if it's brown
flush it down this is a really simple
way to measure how long you're spending
in the shower and just give you a
reminder to keep it short if you can one
thing we try to do is we never try to
you know force anybody in at anything we
don't have any laws of you can only take
a 3-minute shower because we recognize
we all have different needs we can all
reduce our energy use in different ways
and sometimes sometimes after a long day
of final issues something I just needed
a bath and a beer so we come back and
and don't look at the shower coach
most of us eat at the co-op's on campus
and so the co-ops are student-run we do
all the cleaning and cooking for
ourselves there I think about 600 people
on campus in the co-ops and we serve
mostly vegetarian local organic food
that comes from the local farm or other
Amish growers in the area oh I'm pretty
sure these these leeks are all from our
local organic farm that's just a few
blocks down the road and that's actually
where we send the compost from the coop
so you'll see the compost bins around
and we put our food waste in there and
then we send it out to the farm and we
make really healthy soil and then we
grow our vegetables in it and they come
back to the coop and we it's a whole
it's a whole great cycle one of the neat
projects going on this semester is what
we're calling the the light bulb brigade
this is a group of students that are
exchanging compact fluorescent light
bulbs for incandescent bulbs this
neighborhood is only 3 blocks down the
street from our seed house so we're
trying to make an impact right near
where we are yeah so we're happy to swap
out as many bulbs as you like we had a
donor to the college offer to give us
ten thousand light bulbs compact
fluorescent light bulbs CFLs we're
basically going out to community homes
and offering one CFL for every old
incandescent bulb and we've given out
about 8500 light bulbs so far yeah there
we go I think our generation is unique
in how we blend idealism with pragmatism
you know if you act small and you
weatherize your doors and you reuse your
shower water and you do all these little
things then maybe a friend will come
over and see that and realize that it's
fun and easy too and then they'll start
doing it and then a friend of theirs
will start doing it you know we're we're
not exactly the granola kids of the 60s
and 70s who were
you know about restoring America to a
farm economy but we do we really care
about these issues and we care about
making a positive change in the world
but also extremely flexible and fast and
realistic when we're addressing these
issues and I think that's something new
that our generation is bringing
you
